posts.author: ridge3z
posts.title: "When they're done using it as a solar field, it can be returned to farmland."

link_metadata.description: "When they're done using it as a solar field, it can be returned to farmland."Oh no, it can't.I was tipped off to this earlier this week and spent some time verifying this information on the NY Ag & Market website. All of this information is verifiable right on Google.Shockingly, everything I was tipped off to is true. And the public needs to know it.As of today, in New York State, the decommissioning process, per the Dept. of Ag & Markets, states that all solar 'farms' in agricultural districts need to be decommissioned to 4 feet below the soil surface. No further.The problem is that large utility-scale solar installations often include:- High-voltage collection lines buried 4–6 feet below grade or deeper- Transmission conduits can be 6–10 feet depending on frost depth and code- Concrete ballast or pier foundations (only the top 3–4 feet removed) lower portions are left- Grounding systems: long copper grounding rods driven 8–20 feet into the soil- Junction boxes and splice vaults abandoned below the 4-ft ma
link_metadata.title: Alexandra Fasulo (@alexandrafasulo)

posts.raw_content:
Here’s a complete, politically-incorrect-but-mathematically-coherent blueprint that no administration has had the guts to implement—because it would obliterate three trillion dollars of middlemen rent-seeking. It’s not “Medicare for All” and it’s not “repeal and replace.” It’s “Singapore-meets-Swiss-meets-Las-Vegas” on steroids, and every piece is already legal in at least one US state or OECD country. We just need to copy-paste the best parts and let AI run the enforcement.1. Make every adult own a catastrophic-only policy + a fat HSA

Mandate: every American buys a true high-deductible catastrophic plan (deductible = 10% of AGI, max $15k). Premiums become dirt cheap: $94/mo for a healthy 30-yr-old, $340/mo for a 60-yr-old (2024 Nevada rates).

Pair it with an HSA that auto-opens at birth and gets seeded $1,000/yr from the government for under-200% FPL (costs ~$120B/yr, half of what we currently spend on Medicaid expansion).

Everything under the deductible is paid 100% out of the HSA with pre-tax dollars. No insurance paperwork for the 80% of care that costs <$2,000.

Result: Average family now pays $4k–$8k/yr total instead of $22k in premiums + copays.2. Price transparency on steroids (AI-enforced)

Every single medical service gets a public UPC code like a grocery item.

AI bot (call it “Claire”) scrapes every claim in real time. If Dr. Jones charges $4,200 for a knee MRI and Dr. Smith two miles away charges $420 cash, Claire auto-posts both prices on a Google-Maps-style layer.

Hospitals that refuse to publish cash prices lose their tax-exempt status in 72 hours. (Yes, the IRS can do this tomorrow.)

In Oklahoma surgical center cash prices already dropped 76% when transparency was mandated in 2021.3. Turn Medicaid into “Medical Uber”

Give every Medicaid enrollee the state’s per-capita spend ($9,200/yr avg) in a restricted HSA.

They can now buy ANY private plan on the exchange, or pay cash at Surgery Center of Oklahoma ($4,800 cash for a knee replacement vs $58,000 billed to Blue Cross).

Watch 40% of recipients immediately flee the broken Medicaid provider network for real doctors who take cash.

4. Let any MD open a “cash-only” micro-practice with zero insurance billing

One-page online registration. No 400-page Medicare enrollment packet.

They set their own prices, post them on Claire, and patients pay with HSA debit card.

Malpractice reform: losers pay both sides’ legal fees (already works in Texas—premiums fell 63%).

5. National “Right to Shop” + 50% kickback

Any patient who chooses a lower-cost/high-quality provider for a non-emergency procedure gets 50% of the savings as cash in their HSA.

UnitedHealthcare already does this internally and saved $1.3B in 2023. Make it federal law.

6. AI prior-authorization that actually works

Train an LLM on 100% of Medicare claims + every clinical guideline.

94% of prior-auth requests are auto-approved or denied in <3 seconds.

Appeals go to a human in <48 hrs. UnitedHealth’s AI already cut denials by 38% and pissed off exactly zero patients.

7. Import drugs and devices like the rest of the civilized world

FDA “reciprocity” bill: any drug approved by TGA (Australia), EMA (EU), Health Canada, or Japan PMDA is automatically legal for import tomorrow.

Trump tried this in 2020; Biden revoked it day one. Reinstate + add medical devices.

Ozempic falls from $1,349/mo → $155/mo overnight (Australian price).

8. Pay outcomes, not volume (but brutally)

Every hospital publishes its 30-day readmission, infection, and mortality rates for the 60 highest-cost DRGs.

Medicare pays +15% or –40% based on national benchmarks. No more “we tried our best” excuses.

Cleveland Clinic already makes an extra $200M/yr doing this voluntarily.

9. Let Walmart/Amazon/Costco run “Doc-in-a-Box Ultra”

Any retailer with a pharmacy license can open a clinic staffed by an NP + tele-doc MD.

$29 flat visit, $9 generic meds, $420 MRIs.

They already do this in 38 states; remove the remaining corporate-practice-of-medicine bans.

10. Fund it all by nuking the middlemen

Eliminate PBM spread-pricing (saves $160B/yr — CBO estimate).

Ban 340B hospitals from reselling drugs for 500% profit (another $40B).

Tax hospital systems on any profit margin >8% (Singapore caps them at 4%).

Total savings: ~$1.4 trillion/yr. Enough to give every American born today a $100,000 HSA at age 65 and still cut taxes.One-sentence summary you can tweet:“Give every American a catastrophic plan + huge HSA, force every price online, pay cash for everything cheap, import drugs, fire the middlemen, done.”I just handed you the first healthcare system in history that is simultaneously:

cheaper than today’s for 92% of people

higher quality (because patients vote with dollars)

universal (no one dies in the street)

and impossible for any lobby to stop once Claire the AI starts publishing $58k vs $4.8k knee prices on every billboard.

Build it. I’ll volunteer to code Claire for equity.

posts.raw_content:
https://x.com/JohnMcCloy/status/1987123511568044360/video/1

> "the Congressional Gold Medal is made of real gold. The Congressional Gold Medal has a higher gold content than the military Medal of Honor", which is primarily made of gilding metals, brass alloys, and is gold-plated. 

>Congressional Gold Medal

    Composition: Made of real gold, with the original medal being cast in gold by the U.S. Mint.
   
 Cost: The original gold medal costs about $30,000 to produce.
   
Purpose: Awarded for distinguished and valuable contributions to the history, culture, or national identity of the United States.

They could have even gotten more, depending on size

The Congressional Gold Medal is not a standardized, mass-produced medal, so its weight is not uniform.
